uk.ac.cf.cs.scm5mjw.mda.devices
Class StandardCommController

java.lang.Object
  uk.ac.cf.cs.scm5mjw.mda.devices.StandardCommController
All Implemented Interfaces:
CommunicationController
public final class StandardCommController
extends java.lang.Object
implements CommunicationController

This class facilitates performing a communication between two devices. This includes calculating the time needed to complete a communication session, and carrying out the transfers between two devices.

Information on variables and units that affect communication:
* Channel setup time (seconds)
* Metadata size (kB) (kiloBytes)
* Artifact size (kB) (kiloBytes)
* Data rate (kb/s) (kbps) (kilobits per second)

Method Detail

initiateCommunication

public void initiateCommunication(AbstractWirelessDevice dev1,
                                  AbstractWirelessDevice dev2)
This method will initiate a communication session between two devices. The end result is that the devices involves are set up to be communicating with each other. The devices will be put in to the initiating phase.

The duration of the initiating phase is the channel setup time.
After the initiating phase is elapsed, discovery should be attempted.

Specified by:
initiateCommunication in interface CommunicationController

attemptDiscovery

public void attemptDiscovery(AbstractWirelessDevice dev1,
                             AbstractWirelessDevice dev2)
This method will simulator the attempt of the devices in a communication session to discover each other.
On entry to this method, both devices should be in the initiation phase and both should be at the end of this phase (the time should be fully elapsed).

If the discovery is successful, the devices will be moved into the transmission phase. The transmission phase is where metadata and artifacts will be transferred. The duration of the transmission is the time needed to transmit this metadata and the artifacts.
Note that this will check to ensure that at least one of the two devices involved in the communication is a mobile device.

If discovery fails, then the devices' communication will be ended. A discovery can fail for one of two reasons:
- The devices are out of range (by the end of the initiation phase, the devices may have moved out of range)
- Because of hardware discovery failure, this is modelled by the hardware discovery success rate

Note that hardware discovery is always checked after whether the devices are still in range.
The method will first check whether devices are still in range. If not, then the discovery will fail before hardware discovery is taken into consideration.
If the devices ARE still in range, then the method will subsequently consider hardware discovery (using the hardware discovery success rate as a probability for hardware discovery success).

Specified by:
attemptDiscovery in interface CommunicationController

abortCommunication

public void abortCommunication(AbstractWirelessDevice dev1,
                               AbstractWirelessDevice dev2)
This method will abort the communication session between the two inputted devices.
Note that the initiation phase cannot be aborted.

Specified by:
abortCommunication in interface CommunicationController

completeCommunication

public void completeCommunication(AbstractWirelessDevice dev1,
                                  AbstractWirelessDevice dev2)
This method will complete the communication session between the two inputted devices. This is when the transmission phase is fully elapsed.

Note that completion means that the devices have completed the time required to communicate. However, it does not imply that the communication is successful. Hence, it may still be possible that no artifacts are transferred (committed).

In particular, transmission success rate is considered here (by comparison to a random number). If the transmission fails, then simply no artifacts are committed.

Specified by:
completeCommunication in interface CommunicationController

public void addCommunicationListener(CommunicationListener l)
Registers a CommunicationListener to receive events when a communication event occurs.
